Lobbyist Name: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
Specific Details: Key  issues for unemployed people; their personal experiences  and impact of unemployment; work that organisations are undertaking to address these issues.
DPOs Lobbied: Alison Gilliland|Councillor|Dublin City Council::Cathal Boland|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Dermot Lacey|Councillor|Dublin City Council::June Murphy|Councillor|Cork County Council::Michael Cholm Mac Giolla Easbuig|Councillor|Donegal County Council::Michael Kilcoyne|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Richard Finn|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Sorca Clarke|Councillor|Westmeath County Council
Subject Matter: Key  issues for unemployed people; their personal experiences  and impact of unemployment; work that organisations are undertaking to address these issues.
Intended Results: To secure more inclusive, constructive and well resourced social protection, education and training and employment policies and outcomes.
Lobbying Activities: In September the INOU published the 34th edition of the organisation’s E-bulletin. This edition marked a number of anniversaries: the launch of the 25th edition of the INOU’s publication Working for Work; and the 21st anniversary of Kildare Local Employment Service. As Budget 2019 approached the organisation re-iterate the INOU’s key asks. Two of our individual members wrote about the difficulties facing older women securing employment. Other articles covered the Adult Education Survey 2017; JobsPlus Employers Survey; Labour Force Survey Quarter 2, 2018; and developments in JobsIreland.ie. The Economic, Social and Cultural Rights Initiative wrote about what needs to happen for Ireland to realise the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals.|Email|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Bríd O'Brien, INOU Head of Policy and Media

Lobbyist Name: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
Specific Details: In mid-October the INOU's 2019 initial Post-Budget analysis was published on-line and distributed.
DPOs Lobbied: Alison Gilliland|Councillor|Dublin City Council::Cathal Boland|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Dermot Lacey|Councillor|Dublin City Council::June Murphy|Councillor|Cork County Council::Michael Cholm Mac Giolla Easbuig|Councillor|Donegal County Council::Michael Kilcoyne|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Richard Finn|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Sorca Clarke|Councillor|Westmeath County Council
Subject Matter: In mid-October the INOU's 2019 initial Post-Budget analysis was published on-line and distributed.
Intended Results: To assess if Budget 2019 would lead to better outcomes for unemployed people and others of working age, including increased social welfare rates and whether other supports and employment services will meet people's needs and support the realisation of their ambitions.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Bríd O'Brien, INOU Head of Policy and Media

Lobbyist Name: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
Specific Details: Key  issues for unemployed people; their personal experiences  and impact of unemployment; work that organisations are undertaking to address these issues.
DPOs Lobbied: Alison Gilliland|Councillor|Dublin City Council::Cathal Boland|Councillor|Fingal County Council::Dermot Lacey|Councillor|Dublin City Council::June Murphy|Councillor|Cork County Council::Michael Cholm Mac Giolla Easbuig|Councillor|Donegal County Council::Michael Kilcoyne|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Richard Finn|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Sorca Clarke|Councillor|Westmeath County Council
Subject Matter: Key  issues for unemployed people; their personal experiences  and impact of unemployment; work that organisations are undertaking to address these issues.
Intended Results: To secure more inclusive, constructive and well resourced social protection, education and training and employment policies and outcomes.
Lobbying Activities: In November the INOU published the 35th edition of the organisation’s E-bulletin. This edition looked at Budget 2019 and what it delivered for unemployed people. One article highlighted 'Fast Track' and the opportunities it could facilitate. DALC’s article explored the transformative nature of adult education. There were articles marking the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the 1st anniversary of the European Pillar of Social Rights. The INOU Out & About highlighted work undertaken by the Welfare to Work Team. INOU affiliate, BURC talk about the Universal Credit and its implications for people in Northern Ireland. There was the INOU’s submission to the review of the Community Services Programme; an article describing the INOU’s new environmental policy; and an article looking at the Labour Force Survey Households and Family Units.|Email|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Bríd O'Brien, INOU Head of Policy and Media

Specific Details: Educational outcomes for Deaf and Hard of Hearing children
DPOs Lobbied: Sorca Clarke|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Aodhán Ó Ríordáin|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Paul Kehoe|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Educational outcomes for Deaf and Hard of Hearing children
Intended Results: Seeking publication of educational outcomes for Deaf and Hard of Hearing children to ascertain the extent to which the official policy objective - that these children achieve educational outcomes on a par with hearing peers of similar ability (NCSE,2011) - is being achieved.
Lobbying Activities: We emailed a number of members of the Joint Oireachtas Committee on Education in relation to a presentation made on behalf of Chime to the committee on the matter on July 4th 2023. |Email|6-10::Met with Sinn Fein spokesperson on Education. |Meeting|1

Specific Details: End Orphanage volunteering Working Group
Subject Matter: End Orphanage volunteering Working Group
Intended Results: To raise awareness about visiting orphanages, the harmful effect it can have on vulnerable children and the exploitative industries that can develop around this activity.  To influence public and school policies on school trips or other volunteering activities in and to orphanages.
Lobbying Activities:
To ask the Minister for Education if she will develop child-safe guidelines for school trips, including guidance not to visit orphanages; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
Ms Clarke e mailed the Minister of Education about this.
|Meeting|1
